thread.title: Sydney to cop a bucketing this weekend
thread.title_full: Sydney to cop a bucketing this weekend

title: Sydney to cop a bucketing this weekend

organizations.name: bureau of meteorology duty forecaster jordan notara

text:
Share on Twitter 
A LOW is forming off the coast of NSW and is expected to bring torrential rain and flash flooding right in time for the weekend. 
On both Saturday and Sunday 50mm of rain is expected to fall, as a low pressure system moves across to the coast. 
The coming weekend is expected to bring more rain than there has been so far this year, Bureau of Meteorology Duty Forecaster Jordan Notara said. Swimmers at Coogee this morning, as a low is said to be forming off the coast. Picture: John Grainger Source: News Corp Australia Swimmers enjoy a dip on Tuesday morning ahead of the anticipated wet weekend. Picture: John Grainger Source: News Corp Australia 
While the rainy weather is set to continue “the heavy, heavy falls are confined to Saturday and Sunday,” Mr Notara said. 
“There is a chance of localised flash flooding, and it will depend on how far inland the low falls,” he said. 
He said that all along the east coast could expect wild weather with the possibility of storms. Parts of the eastern seaboard could receive more than a month's worth of rain during the next week. #9News https://t.co/Al6TrGSuZf pic.twitter.com/9S6E7fnYS6 — Nine News Australia (@9NewsAUS) February 27, 2017 
“The actual low will bring an unstable atmosphere … there will be a good chance there will be isolated storms forming” 
This type of weather event was typical for this time of year as the seasons change and warm temperatures collided with cooler air. 
The torrential downpour is expected just two weeks after a hailstorm lashed Sydney, with massive hailstorms causing millions in damage. A hailstorm lashed Sydney on the Friday February 18. Source: Supplied
